text: hey everyone here's an interesting bit
of electronics history this is a usage
counter so it tells you how many hours a
piece of equipment has been used it just
has two terminals on the back and these
are just mounting lugs here these don't
electrically connect to anything and
when we put 12.6 volts on the terminals
this thing starts counting the number of
hours what's interesting is that it has
no mechanical parts really and it's also
completely passive and the way it works
is that has this thin glass tube that
has mercury in it but notice there's a
little gap right here and this is where
you read the meter so this is times 100
and this is the Russian word for hour so
500 hours the full scale is 2500 hours
and the way this works is when we put
electricity on here
the mercury from this side of the column
is actually transferred through that gap
which is filled with electrolyte to this
other side so the gap actually creeps
along as we put power through this thing
and that's what saves the timer that's
what how you can read off the time in
some sense it's not tamper proof at all
because all we have to do is switch the
polarity of the power and the gaff will
start moving back the other way however
if we run it long enough where the gap
goes off the end of the column then it's
done you can't ever reset it because the
gap is missing and there's nothing to do
this transfer anymore
this draws about 60 micro amps at the
rated 12 point 6 volts and I made a
little time-lapse just showing what this
thing looks like under a microscope so
we have a chance of actually seeing the
gap move the time-lapse spans about 8
hours today that I was running it at a
slightly higher voltage to try to get
some more speed out of it technically
this device is called a kilometer
because what it's actually measuring is
the amount of total charge that we've
put through it the number of mercury
atoms that are transferred across that
gap is directly proportional to the
number of electrons now the amount of
the total charge that we've put through
this device so if we run it at a higher
voltage it will very happily move the
gap along at a higher rate because it's
just
measuring the the total charge and
higher voltage means more current more
electrons and more atoms being moved
when I first started to do the numbers I
realized that there must be a current
divider inside this thing and so I
cracked it open and sure enough there is
a resistor network that looks like this
and it gives us about about a ten to one
current divider so that the actual
number of electrons flowing through the
tube the mercury capillary is about
one-tenth the number flowing through the
main circuit I wanted to see if I could
figure out how fast the counters should
run based on the actual physics involved
and it actually turned out fairly close
so I measured the capillary diameter at
about 0.35 millimeters and then
calculated the area and the molecular
weight of mercury is about 200 grams and
then with the density we can figure out
that one mole of mercury is about almost
15,000 cubic millimeters and then if we
dub divided by the area of that
capillary we can figure out that one
mole of mercury atoms is about 1.5 times
10 to the 5 linear millimeters on that
scale per mole the reason we want to
know this in terms of moles are a number
of mer of mercury atoms is because the
actual electroplating or electro
transfer electrochemistry really that's
happening in there is dependent on the
number of electrons and in this case I'm
guessing that the mercury is in a two
plus charge state inside there I don't
know what the electrolyte is but it's
some kind of probably aqueous solution
and so when the mercury comes off it'll
be in two plus so we actually need two
electrons to get one mercury ion across
that gap and then we have six point two
times 10 to the 18 electrons per Coulomb
and 6.02 times 10 to the 23 items per
mole so then we end up with this amount
of moles per coulombs we've basically
figured out how much electricity it's
going to take to move a mole of stuff
and we also know how much linear space a
mole is going to take up
that capillary so then if we multiply
those two numbers together we get about
3/4 of a millimeter per Coulomb so
that's pretty convenient so if we had 1
amp for one second that would be 1
Coulomb and we should get 0.77
millimeters of travel so as it happens
500 hours on this scale is exactly 8
millimeters and so I did 8 divided by
that rate that we just came up with and
came up with ten point three coulombs
but that's ten point three coulombs
through the capillary if we use that ten
to one current divider that's actually a
hundred and one coulombs of total charge
and this thing is drawing about 62 micro
amps so if we calculate it all out we
get four hundred and fifty three hours
calculated when it really should be five
hundred so I think that's probably
within the the margin of error here I
think probably the biggest iffy
measurement is the capillary diameter
and also the resistance of that gap
through the electrolyte I just had to
took a guess at that okay I hope you
found that interesting see you next time
bye
